newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean bankers questioned over Hanbo scandal.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean bankers questioned over Hanbo scandal.

text.p: South Korean state prosecutors on Friday continued questioning three of the country's current or former bank chiefs over the Hanbo Steel loan scandal.
Korea Exchange Bank president Chang Myung-son, Korea Development Bank president Kim Shi-hyung and Cho Hung Bank's former president, Lee Chong-yeon, were summoned on Thursday.
"They are being questioned now. But I can't say whether they will be returned home without being charged," one prosecution official told Reuters.
The state Korean Broadcasting System radio said the three would not face any legal action and would be allowed home later on Friday, New Year's Eve in Korea.
State prosecutors have been investigating the financial failure of Hanbo Steel, which piled up some five trillion won ($5.8 billion) in loans from banks and financial institutions.
Hanbo is seeking court receivership. The nation's largest steelmaker, Pohang Iron and Steel Co, has officially accepted an invitation to help run Hanbo on behalf of creditors.

Chung Tae-soo, founder of the Hanbo Group of which Hanbo Steel is the flagship, and two commercial bank heads -- Sheen Kwang-shik of Korea First Bank and Woo Chan-mok of Cho Hung -- have been arrested on charges of bribery.
The arrests brought to 18 the total number of bankers who have been jailed or forced to resign since Kim swept to power in 1993 on an anti-graft platform.
Most were found to have accepted bribes from borrowers.
